improved_solutions:
# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We consider a charged particle that is free to move on an infinitely extended, horizontal plane.  
A two‚Äìdimensional polar coordinate system  
‚ÄÑ‚ÄÑ‚Ä¢ radial coordinate `r (‚â•0)`  
‚ÄÑ‚ÄÑ‚Ä¢ polar angle `Œ∏` (measured counter-clock-wise from the positive x‚Äìaxis)  
is attached to that plane.  The orthonormal basis is therefore  
\((\mathbf e_r,\mathbf e_\theta,\mathbf e_z)\), with \(\mathbf e_z\) pointing vertically upward.

Given data  

1.  Magnetic field (static, non-uniform)  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉdirection‚ÄÉ\(+\mathbf e_z\)  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉmagnitude‚ÄÉ\(B(r)=\dfrac{m\,v}{q\,\sqrt{a\,r}}\) ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ(\(a>0\) and \(v\) are constants).

2.  Particle properties  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉmass \(m_p\;(=M)\), charge \(q_p\;(=e)\)  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉcharge‚Äìto‚Äìmass ratio  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ\[
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ\dfrac eM=\dfrac{3q}{2\sqrt2\,m}.
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ\]

3.  Initial conditions at \(t=0\)  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉposition‚ÄÉ\(r(0)=0,\; \theta(0)=0\)  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉvelocity‚ÄÉ\(\dot r(0)=v_0>0,\; \dot\theta(0)=0\).  
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ(The velocity is directed along the initial polar axis, i.e. purely radial.)

Idealisations / assumptions  

‚Ä¢  Only the magnetic Lorentz force acts; no electric or other forces are present.  
‚Ä¢  Motion is non-relativistic; since \(\mathbf v\perp\mathbf B\) at all times, the
   magnetic force does no work and the speed of the particle remains constant at the
   initial value \(v_0\).

Objective‚ÄÉDetermine the trajectory \(r(\theta)\) of the particle.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 1 ‚Äì Lorentz-force equations in plane polar coordinates
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\mathbf F=e\,\mathbf v\times\mathbf B}\]  
\[\boxed{\mathbf v=\dot r\,\mathbf e_r+r\dot\theta\,\mathbf e_\theta}\]  
\[\boxed{\begin{cases}
\mathbf a\!\cdot\!\mathbf e_r=\ddot r-r\dot\theta^{2}\\
\mathbf a\!\cdot\!\mathbf e_\theta=r\ddot\theta+2\dot r\dot\theta
\end{cases}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf v\times\mathbf B
     &=\bigl(\dot r\,\mathbf e_r+r\dot\theta\,\mathbf e_\theta\bigr)\times
       \bigl(B\,\mathbf e_{z}\bigr)                                         \nonumber\\
     &=B\bigl(r\dot\theta\,\mathbf e_r-\dot r\,\mathbf e_\theta\bigr),       \label{eq:vxB}\tag{1}\\
M(\ddot r-r\dot\theta^{2})
     &=e\,B\,r\dot\theta,                                                   \label{eq:radial}\tag{2}\\
M(r\ddot\theta+2\dot r\dot\theta)
     &=-e\,B\,\dot r.                                                       \label{eq:azim}\tag{3}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 2 ‚Äì First integral for \(r^{2}\dot\theta\)
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\tfrac d{dt}\!\bigl(r^{2}\dot\theta\bigr)=r^{2}\ddot\theta+2r\dot r\dot\theta}\]  
\[\boxed{B(r)=\dfrac{m\,v}{q\,\sqrt{a\,r}}}\]  
\[\boxed{\dfrac eM=\dfrac{3q}{2\sqrt2\,m}}\]

Derivation  
Multiply Eq. \eqref{eq:azim} by \(r\) and introduce the boxed time derivative:
\[
\begin{align}
M\,\frac d{dt}\!\bigl(r^{2}\dot\theta\bigr)
     &=-e\,B(r)\,r\dot r                                               \nonumber\\
\frac d{dt}\!\bigl(r^{2}\dot\theta\bigr)
     &=-\frac eM\,B(r)\,r\dot r                                        \nonumber\\
     &=-\frac{3q}{2\sqrt2\,m}\;\frac{m v}{q\sqrt{a\,r}}\;r\dot r       \nonumber\\
     &=-\frac{3v}{2\sqrt{2a}}\;r^{1/2}\dot r.                          \label{eq:step2}\tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

Change variable from \(t\) to \(r\) (\(dr=\dot r\,dt\)) and integrate from
\(r=0\) (where \(r^{2}\dot\theta\) is finite) to an arbitrary \(r>0\):
\[
\begin{align}
r^{2}\dot\theta
     &=-\frac{3v}{2\sqrt{2a}}\int_{0}^{r}u^{1/2}\,du
      =-\frac{3v}{2\sqrt{2a}}\;\frac{2}{3}r^{3/2}                     \nonumber\\
     &=-\frac{v}{\sqrt{2a}}\;r^{3/2}.                                 \label{eq:r2theta}\tag{5}
\end{align}
\]

Consequently
\[
\boxed{\dot\theta=-\frac{v}{\sqrt{2a\,r}}}\qquad(r>0).                \label{eq:thetadot}\tag{6}
\]

(Near \(r=0\), \(\dot\theta\) diverges like \(r^{-1/2}\), but the tangential
speed \(r\dot\theta\) remains finite and vanishes as \(r^{1/2}\); hence the
initial direction is purely radial as required.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 3 ‚Äì Radial speed from the constancy of the total speed
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\dot r^{2}+(r\dot\theta)^{2}=v_{0}^{2}}\]

Derivation  
Using Eq. \eqref{eq:thetadot},
\[
\begin{align}
r\dot\theta &=-\frac{v\,r}{\sqrt{2a\,r}}
              =-v\sqrt{\frac{r}{2a}},                                   \label{eq:tangspeed}\tag{7}\\
\dot r^{2}  &=v_{0}^{2}-\Bigl(v\sqrt{\tfrac{r}{2a}}\Bigr)^{2}
              =v_{0}^{2}-\frac{v^{2}r}{2a}.                             \label{eq:rdotsq}\tag{8}
\end{align}
\]

Choosing the positive root (the particle is moving outward initially),
\[
\boxed{\dot r
       =v_{0}\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{2a\,v_{0}^{2}}\;r}},\qquad
0\le r\le r_{\max}.                                                    \label{eq:rdot}\tag{9}
\]

The turning point, where \(\dot r=0\), is
\[
\boxed{r_{\max}=\frac{2a\,v_{0}^{2}}{v^{2}}}.                          \label{eq:rmax}\tag{10}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 4 ‚Äì Differential equation \(\dfrac{dr}{d\theta}\)
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\dfrac{dr}{d\theta}=\dfrac{\dot r}{\dot\theta}}\]

Derivation  
From Eqs. \eqref{eq:thetadot} and \eqref{eq:rdot},
\[
\begin{align}
\frac{dr}{d\theta}
   &=\frac{v_{0}\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^{2}}{2a v_{0}^{2}}\,r}}
           {-\dfrac{v}{\sqrt{2a\,r}}}                                  \nonumber\\
   &=-\sqrt{r_{\max}r-r^{2}}.                                          \label{eq:drdtheta}\tag{11}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 5 ‚Äì Integration to obtain the trajectory \(r(\theta)\)
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\displaystyle\int\frac{dr}{\sqrt{r_{\max}r-r^{2}}}=-\int d\theta}\]

Derivation  
Make the substitution \(r=r_{\max}\sin^{2}\phi\;(0\le\phi\le\pi)\):
\[
dr=2r_{\max}\sin\phi\cos\phi\,d\phi,\qquad
\sqrt{r_{\max}r-r^{2}}=r_{\max}\sin\phi\cos\phi.
\]

Hence \(\dfrac{dr}{\sqrt{r_{\max}r-r^{2}}}=2\,d\phi\), and
Eq. \eqref{eq:drdtheta} becomes
\[
2\,d\phi=-\,d\theta\quad\Longrightarrow\quad \phi=-\frac{\theta}{2}+C.
\]

Because \(r=0\) when \(\theta=0\), we have \(\phi=0\) there,
so \(C=0\): \(\phi=-\theta/2\).

Therefore
\[
\begin{align}
r(\theta)
   &=r_{\max}\sin^{2}\!\Bigl(-\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)
    =r_{\max}\sin^{2}\!\Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)                    \nonumber\\
   &=\frac{r_{\max}}{2}\bigl(1-\cos\theta\bigr).                       \label{eq:rtheta}\tag{12}
\end{align}
\]

Finally substitute \(r_{\max}\) from Eq. \eqref{eq:rmax}:
\[
r(\theta)=a\left(\frac{v_{0}}{v}\right)^{2}\bigl(1-\cos\theta\bigr)
         =2a\left(\frac{v_{0}}{v}\right)^{2}\sin^{2}\frac{\theta}{2}. \nonumber
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
\boxed{\,r(\theta)=a\left(\frac{v_{0}}{v}\right)^{2}\!\bigl(1-\cos\theta\bigr)
      =2a\left(\frac{v_{0}}{v}\right)^{2}\!\sin^{2}\!\frac{\theta}{2}\,}
\end{align}
\]

(The curve is a cardioid scaled by the factor \(\left(\dfrac{v_{0}}{v}\right)^{2}\).  
When \(v=v_{0}\) the classical cardioid \(r=a(1-\cos\theta)\) is recovered.)

questions:
Consider a metal beam with a width of $a$, thickness of $h$, and Young's modulus of $E$. The beam is placed on supports spaced at a distance $l$, and it is assumed that the length of the metal beam is slightly greater than $l$. A weight with a mass of $m$ is placed in the middle of the beam. Assume the angle between the beam and the horizontal line is very small, neglect friction and the weight of the beam, and take the gravitational acceleration as $g$.

Hint: Since the beam has thickness, it develops a situation where the inner side is compressed and the outer side is stretched when in equilibrium. Although the net force at the interface is zero, a torque is generated. This also causes every part of the beam to experience compression/stretch, thereby storing potential energy.

After the weight reaches equilibrium, apply a small horizontal perturbation along the rod‚Äôs direction to the weight and determine the vibration angular frequency of the system.
solutions:
(1) Using the point where the heavy object is suspended as the origin, and the horizontal direction as the $\pmb{\mathscr{x}}$ axis, and the vertical direction as the $\textit{\textbf{y}}$ axis, establish a coordinate system.

First, consider a small curved metal beam segment with a central angle of $\theta$ and radius of $\scriptstyle{\mathcal{R}}$, then the strain at $z$ is:  

$$
\epsilon = \frac{(R+z)\theta - R\theta}{R\theta} = \frac{z}{R}
$$

Resulting moment:  

$$
M = \int_{-\frac{h}{2}}^{\frac{h}{2}}\frac{E a}{R}z^{2}d z = \frac{E a h^{3}}{12R}
$$

Given the approximation condition ${y}^{\prime}\ll1$:  

$$
R = {\frac{(1+y^{\prime2})^{\frac{3}{2}}}{|y^{\prime\prime}|}} \approx {\frac{1}{|y^{\prime\prime}|}}
$$

Substitute into the previous equation:  

$$
M = {\frac{E a h^{3}|y^{\prime\prime}|}{12}}
$$

For the part of the metal beam with $\mathfrak{x}(\mathfrak{x}>0)$ and above, set up the moment equilibrium at the $\pmb{x}$ position:  

$$
M = \frac{m g}{2}(\frac{l}{2}-x)
$$

Substitute into the previous equation:  

$$
y^{\prime\prime} = \frac{6m g}{E a h^{3}}(\frac{l}{2}-x)
$$

Initial conditions:  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{y(0)=0}\ {y^{\prime}(0)=0}\end{array}
$$

Integrating yields:  

$$

# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation  
We have a slender, homogeneous, isotropic metal beam of rectangular cross‚Äìsection  
‚Ä¢ width (into the page) = a  
‚Ä¢ thickness (vertical) = h  

The beam is simply supported at two points that are a distance l apart (left support at x = ‚àí l‚ÅÑ2, right support at x = + l‚ÅÑ2).  
A point mass m rests on the upper surface of the beam.  The mass can slide without friction along the beam so that its horizontal coordinate x can change.

Assumptions  
1. Weight of the beam is neglected; only the point load P = mg acts.  
2. Small deflections and small slopes ‚áí Euler‚ÄìBernoulli beam theory applies (plane sections remain plane, |dy/dx| ‚â™ 1).  
3. Material behaviour is linear‚Äìelastic with Young‚Äôs modulus E.  
4. The initial static equilibrium position of the mass is at mid‚Äìspan (x = 0).  
5. A very small additional horizontal displacement q (|q| ‚â™ l) is imposed and the mass is released; we look for the resulting small‚Äêamplitude horizontal oscillations.  
6. Gravitational acceleration is g and remains constant.

Define the dimensionless eccentricity  
‚ÄÉŒµ ‚â° q/l‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ(|Œµ| ‚â™ 1)  
so that after the perturbation the distances of the point load from the supports are  

‚ÄÉa‚ÇÅ = l/2 (1 + 2Œµ),‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉb‚ÇÅ = l/2 (1 ‚àí 2Œµ),‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉa‚ÇÅ + b‚ÇÅ = l.

Our goal is to find the angular frequency œâ of the resulting small horizontal vibrations.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 1: Moment‚Äìcurvature relation and section property  
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions  
\[\boxed{M(x)=E\,I\,\kappa(x)=E\,I\,\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}}\]  
\[\boxed{I=\dfrac{a\,h^{3}}{12}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
M(x)=E\,\frac{a h^{3}}{12}\,\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} .
\label{eq:MC}\tag{1}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 2: Reactions of the simply supported beam under an eccentric point load  
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\sum F_{y}=0:\;R_{L}+R_{R}=P}\]  
\[\boxed{\sum M_{\text{about\;load}}=0:\;R_{L}\,a_{1}=R_{R}\,b_{1}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
R_{L}&=\frac{P\,b_{1}}{l}= \frac{mg}{2}\bigl(1-2\varepsilon\bigr),\nonumber\\
R_{R}&=\frac{P\,a_{1}}{l}= \frac{mg}{2}\bigl(1+2\varepsilon\bigr).
\label{eq:Reac}\tag{2}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 3: Vertical deflection at the load point  
Principle/Original Formula/Assumption  
\[\boxed{\delta(x=a_{1})=\dfrac{P\,a_{1}^{2}\,b_{1}^{2}}{3\,E\,I\,l}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
\delta(\varepsilon)
&=\frac{mg}{3\,E\,I\,l}
     \left[\frac{l}{2}(1+2\varepsilon)\right]^{2}
     \left[\frac{l}{2}(1-2\varepsilon)\right]^{2} \nonumber\\[4pt]
&=\frac{mg\,l^{3}}{48\,E\,I}\,
     \bigl(1-4\varepsilon^{2}\bigr)^{2}.
\label{eq:delta_eps}\tag{3}
\end{align}
\]
For Œµ = 0 (centred load)  
\[
\delta_{0}= \frac{mg\,l^{3}}{48\,E\,I}.
\label{eq:delta0}\tag{4}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 4: Bending strain energy of the beam  
Principle/Original Formula/Assumption  
\[\boxed{U_{b}= \dfrac{1}{2}\int_{-l/2}^{\,l/2}\!\!\dfrac{M^{2}(x)}{E\,I}\,dx
        = \dfrac{P^{2}a_{1}^{2}b_{1}^{2}}{6\,E\,I\,l}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
U_{b}(\varepsilon)
&=\frac{(mg)^{2}a_{1}^{2}b_{1}^{2}}{6\,E\,I\,l}  \nonumber\\
&=\frac{(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{96\,E\,I}\,
    \bigl(1-4\varepsilon^{2}\bigr)^{2}.
\label{eq:Ub_eps}\tag{5}
\end{align}
\]
The change with respect to the centred configuration is (expand to second order):
\[
\begin{align}
\Delta U_{b} &\equiv U_{b}(\varepsilon)-U_{b}(0)\nonumber\\
&=\frac{(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{96\,E\,I}\,
   \bigl[(1-4\varepsilon^{2})^{2}-1\bigr]  \nonumber\\
&=-\frac{(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{E\,a\,h^{3}}\;\varepsilon^{2}
   +\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{4}),
\label{eq:dUb}\tag{6}
\end{align}
\]
where \(I=a h^{3}/12\) has been used.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 5: Gravitational potential energy of the point mass  
Principle/Original Formula/Assumption  
\[\boxed{U_{g}=-\,m g\,\delta}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
\Delta U_{g}&=U_{g}(\varepsilon)-U_{g}(0)
           =-\,mg\,[\delta(\varepsilon)-\delta_{0}] \nonumber\\
&=-\,mg\,\frac{mg\,l^{3}}{48\,E\,I}\,
   \bigl[(1-4\varepsilon^{2})^{2}-1\bigr] \nonumber\\
&=+\frac{2\,(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{E\,a\,h^{3}}\;
   \varepsilon^{2}+ \mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{4}).
\label{eq:dUg}\tag{7}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 6: Total potential energy, effective spring constant, and natural frequency  
Principle/Original Formula/Assumption  
\[\boxed{U_{\text{tot}}=\Delta U_{b}+\Delta U_{g}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
\Delta U_{\text{tot}}
&=\left[-\frac{(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{E\,a\,h^{3}}
        +\frac{2\,(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{E\,a\,h^{3}}\right]\varepsilon^{2}
  +\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{4})\nonumber\\
&=\frac{(mg)^{2}l^{3}}{E\,a\,h^{3}}\;\varepsilon^{2}
  +\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{4}).                     \nonumber\\[6pt]
\intertext{Replacing \(\varepsilon = q/l\):}
\Delta U_{\text{tot}}
&=\frac{(mg)^{2}l\,q^{2}}{E\,a\,h^{3}}
   =\frac{1}{2}\,K\,q^{2},\nonumber\\
\boxed{K}&=\frac{2\,(mg)^{2}l}{E\,a\,h^{3}}.
\label{eq:K}\tag{8}
\end{align}
\]

The kinetic energy of the mass (moving only horizontally) is  
\[\boxed{T=\tfrac12\,m\,\dot q^{2}}.\]

Applying Lagrange‚Äôs equation for the single coordinate q,

‚ÄÉm \(\ddot q\) + K q = 0,

the angular frequency of the small oscillation is  
\[
\boxed{\omega^{2}=\frac{K}{m}=
        \frac{2\,m\,g^{2}\,l}{E\,a\,h^{3}}}.
\label{eq:omega2}\tag{9}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  
\[
\begin{align}
\boxed{\displaystyle
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2\,m\,g^{2}\,l}{E\,a\,h^{3}}}\;}
\end{align}
\]
